advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gerard Touitou</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The computing answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> WONDER COMPUTE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTOROLA AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>In fact, this advert didn't promote the Macintosh II computer but the 68020 microprocessor.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...While Apple's choice of the MC 68020 was a smart move, there's no licence on genius: the 68020 is the microprocessor of choice in advanced business system design by such industry leaders as Altos, Alpha Micro, Casio, C.Itoh, Fujitsu, Honneywell Bull, NEC, NCR, Olivetti, Plexus, Ricoh, Sanyo, Sharp, TI, Toshiba and Unisys...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Yeno DPC 64 leaves major of MSX"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The personal computer of Mr sales manager"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a French Commodore-PC brochure.<br><br> 'Hats off to Commodore!' </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Enter the game of computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
In fact, two different systems were called Timex 2048. The first, called TS-2048 (for Timex-Sinclair) was designed by Timex USA but never passed the prototype stage. It was a 16K version of the TS-2068 with the same silver case but reduced features, a Kempston joystick interface and additional video modes. At the time when it was ready to be launched, the market had moved to 48K and 64K systems, and there was no future for a new 16K machine.
The second, named TC-2048 (for Timex Computers) was designed and made in Portugal by the Timex Portuguese subsidiary. It kept some features of the US prototype - joystick interface and extra video modes - and was 99% compatible with the ZX Spectrum. Slight differences in BASIC ROM and edge connector prevented some rare game software or peripherals to run correctly.
However, it was a better quality machine than the genuine Sinclair. Plastic-key keyboard was more reliable and had a full-sized space bar, a power switch and power Led were added and the custom ULA chip offered better IRQ and memory management.
Thanks to its extra video modes, the TC-2048 was able to display 80 columns text. Coupled with an external floppy disc unit - generally, the FDD-3000 - it could run CP/M O.S. and software.
As Timex Computers was only allowed to distribute the TC-2048 in countries where the Sinclair Spectrum wasn't established, it was only sold in Portugal and Poland. it met a great success in both countries where several ten-thousands machines were sold.
Thanks to Alejandro Cifuentes for the picture.
computer.graphics: 256 x 192 dots in colour mode, 512 x 192 dots in monochrome mode
computer.name: TC-2048
computer.peripherals: All the Sinclair Spectrum and third party expansions
computer.ports: Tape recorder IN & OUT, RF TV video output, Composite video output, Joystick connector (DB9), expansion bus connector
computer.power: External power supply unit (ground in the center), 9v DC at 1000 mA.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>We can see here the joystick connector</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> (1) External AC power supply connector<br> (2) Spectrum compatible I/O connector<br> (3) Composite video output<br> (4) Tape recorder In/Out jacks<br> (5) RF/TV modulator</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TC-2048 MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Joystick connector<br> <b>(2)</b> RF/TV modulator<br> <b>(3)</b> Tape recorder In/Out jacks<br> <b>(4)</b> Composite video output<br> <b>(5)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Spectrum compatible I/O connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Z80A processor, here a Nec D780C version<br> <b>(8)</b> 16 KB ROM chip holding the BASIC interpreter <br> <b>(9)</b> External AC power supply connector<br> <b>(10)</b> On/Off switch<br> <b>(11)</b> internal 5v DC regulator and its cooler<br> <b>(12)</b> 4264 RAM chips<br> <b>(13)</b> Custom ULA chip made by NCR<br> <b>(14)</b> Loudspeaker<br><p class="petitgris">Picture from <b>Alejandro Cifuentes</b></p></blockquote>

computer.text: 32 chars. x 24 rows, 80 columns extended mode
